Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Immersive Audio-visualization of Seismic Wave Fields in the Earth (EarthScope Education & Outreach)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The core of this project is the development of a methodology (software
and hardware) to produce synchronized visual and sonic representations
of seismic wave fields in the Earth. Coupling these senses enables
people, from the general public to seasoned seismologists, to
appreciate and perceive an enormous richness in the patterns of
seismic wave fields. The aim is not to simulate the experience of an
earthquake, but to render the physics of wave propagation in the globe
and the nature of earthquake physics into a completely tactile
experience, unlike anything anyone has ever perceived. The working
group is comprised of earth scientists, astrophysicists, sound and
graphics engineers and educators, from the Lamont Doherty Earth
Observatory (LDEO), Princeton University, and the American Museum of
Natural History (AMNH).

The images and sounds are generated from both USArray and GSN data, as
well as from simulations generated with the spectral element method
(SEM), using the SPECFEM3D software. Sounds are generated by shifting
the frequency of the seismic signal into the range of human hearing,
and are filtered and stretched in time to optimize the coupled visual
and sonic effects. Once the methodology is in place, it will take two
general forms:

First, a web-based format that allows people to choose earthquakes and
seismic data to listen to, with images produced by either a dense
array of seismometers (i.e. the ground motion visualizations (GMVs)
produced by IRIS of the Transportable Array data) or a simulation of
the seismic wave field (i.e. by SPECFEM3D). This format will be useful
for classroom and laboratory purposes, and interactive museum
exhibits, as well as for exploratory observation of raw data by
seismologists.

Second, a version will be developed for the Hayden Planetarium at the
American Museum of Natural History, in New York City. The images,
projected on the planetarium dome, will include the surface of the
Earth rendered as a membrane and also a volumetric rendering in which
the observer will see 3D wave fronts propagating throughout the globe.
The sounds will be tuned to the large speaker array in the
Planetarium. Within the context of this project, several Public
Programs will occur in the Planetarium, in which the immersive
experience of listening to the Earth will be guided by the production
team. These Public Programs are the essential first step towards
developing a full planetarium show on the dynamics of the Earth at
AMNH.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this Education & Outreach project, we have developed new methods for representing seismic data with sounds and movies, to engage the public in questions of what earthquakes and seismic waves teach us about the planet. The main venue for this development was the Hayden Planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History (collaborators on this project) in New York City, in the context of the “SeismoDome” program that we have performed three times on the grant funds. The program will likely continue to grow at the Hayden and be developed for other planetariums. Some of the movies developed for Seismodome are distributed on our vimeo channel: http://www.vimeo.com/seismicsoundlab and our website: http://www.seismicsoundlab/org. These movies are being incorporated into classroom curricula and other informal science education settings. 

 

The Seismodome program uses seismic data to explain numerous aspects of how the Earth works. We compress geologic and seismic time scales into short movies that humans can digest. The show consists of about 25 movies that convey (1) the complex patterns of seismicity that outline the plate boundaries and subducting slabs, (2) the patterns of wave propagation in the planet after an earthquake that inform us of the structure of the plates, convecting mantle and core, and (3) the source and meaning of the ambient seismic noise in the solid earth, caused by ocean wave interactions.  In (2), we use both simulations (run by the Princeton arm of this grant) and USArray data to visualize and sonify seismic wave fields, to explain the nature and value of the EarthScope program. We are currently developing new methods of visualizing mantle tomography, at both global and regional US scales. These images will be incorporated into the next an subsequent Seismodome shows. We address questions of earthquake forecasting and the nature of the randomness of seismicity by rendering earthquake “catalogs” in time and space. We contrast these to the movies of ocean wave height (i.e. weather) to convey the difficulty of predicting earthquakes compared to weather. An underlying aim is to expand people’s sense of time and space by progressively compressing the time scales of data over the course of the show, such that people leave with a greatly expanded sense of the shortness of our lifetimes and the magnitude of the forces that shape our planet and our lives.
